<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/could-->
<h1><i class="i">Could</i></h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><div class="section_anchor" id="could-form"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Could</i>: form</h2></div><div class="content"><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Affirmative (+) form</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Could</i> comes first in the verb phrase (after the subject and before another verb):<span class="target"/></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">could</b> have lunch early.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p"><i class="i">Could</i> cannot be used with another modal verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">could</b> drive to France</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">We could might drive to France</s>. or <s class="s">We might could drive to France</s>.</p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Negative (−) form</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">The negative form of <i class="i">could</i> is <i class="i">couldn’t</i>. We don’t use <i class="i">don’t</i>/<i class="i">doesn’t</i>/<i class="i">didn’t</i> with <i class="i">could</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">couldn’t</b> lift that. It’s too heavy.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">He didn’t could lift that</s> …</p></blockquote><p class="p">We can use the full form <i class="i">could not</i> in formal contexts or when we want to emphasise something:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Fabio was frightened. He <b class="b">could not</b> move his arm. It was stuck.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Question (?) form</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">The subject and <i class="i">could</i> change position to form questions. We don’t use <i class="i">do/does/did</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Could</b> I pay by credit card?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Do I could pay by credit card?</s></p></blockquote><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i> and <i class="i">couldn’t</i> in question tags:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I could come back tomorrow, <b class="b">couldn’t</b> I?</i></p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_1' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
</div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="could-uses"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Could</i>: uses</h2></div><div class="content"><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Possibility</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We often use <i class="i">could</i> to express possibility in the present and the future.</p><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Compare</span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It<b class="b">’s</b> blue.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">I am certain that it is blue. It’s a fact.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It <b class="b">could b</b>e blue.</i> (present)</p></blockquote><p class="p">I’m not certain that it is blue.</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The storm <b class="b">will get</b> worse.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">I’m certain that the storm will get worse.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The storm <b class="b">could get</b> worse.</i> (future)</p></blockquote><p class="p">I’m not certain that the storm will get worse.</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can#can__2"><i class="i">Can</i>: uses </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Suggestions</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We often use <i class="i">could</i> to make suggestions:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Will’s party is fancy-dress</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">It’s Halloween</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">C:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Oh right. I</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">could</i></b> <i class="i">go as Julius Caesar</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Again? How many times have you done that?</i></p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’ve got to be in the meeting at 10 and the train doesn’t get in until 10.15</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">Could</i></b> <i class="i">you get an earlier train?</i></p></div></div></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Permission</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i> to ask for permission. <i class="i">Could</i> is more formal and polite than <i class="i">can</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Could</b> I ask you a personal question?</i></p></blockquote><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">We don’t use <i class="i">could</i> to give or refuse permission. We use <i class="i">can</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">Could</i></b> <i class="i">I leave early today?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, you can./No, you can’t</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Yes, you could./No, you couldn’t</s>.</p></blockquote></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can"><i class="i">Can</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_2' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
</div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="could-past"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Could</i>: past</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We don’t usually use <i class="i">could</i> to talk about single events that happened in the past.</p><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Past achievement</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">When actual past achievements are <span class="target"/>mentioned, we usually use <i class="i">was/were able to</i> or <i class="i">managed to</i> but not <i class="i">could</i> in affirmative clauses. This is because they are facts, rather than possibilities:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">was able to/managed to</b> buy a wonderful bag to match my shoes.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">I could buy a wonderful bag to match my shoes</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We hired a car and we <b class="b">were able to/managed to</b> drive 1,000 miles in one week.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">We hired a car and we could drive 1,000 miles in one week</s>.</p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Ability</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i> to talk about past ability:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">When I was young, I <b class="b">could</b> easily touch my toes.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Possibility</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could have + -ed</i> form to talk about possibility in the past:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">could have been</b> a lawyer.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They <b class="b">could have taken</b> a taxi home instead of walking and getting wet.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Janette <b class="b">couldn’t have done</b> any better.</i></p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_3' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Guessing and predicting: <i class="i"><i class="i">couldn’t</i></i> as the negative of <i class="i"><i class="i">must</i></i></h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">When we want to guess or predict something, we use <i class="i">couldn’t</i> as the negative form of <i class="i">must</i>. We use <i class="i">couldn’t have +</i> -<i class="i">ed</i> form as the negative form of <i class="i">must have +</i> -<i class="i">ed. Couldn’t</i> and <i class="i">couldn’t have +</i> -<i class="i">ed</i> form express strong possibility:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She must have made a mistake. It <b class="b">couldn’t be true</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">A firework <b class="b">couldn’t have done</b> all that damage.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can"><i class="i">Can</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title"><i class="i"><i class="i">Could</i></i> + <i class="i"><i class="i">smell</i></i>, <i class="i"><i class="i">taste</i></i>, <i class="i"><i class="i">think</i></i>, <i class="i"><i class="i">believe</i></i>, etc.</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i> to refer to single events that happened in the past, with verbs of the senses (<i class="i">smell</i>, <i class="i">taste</i>, <i class="i">see</i>, <i class="i">hear</i>, <i class="i">touch</i>, etc.) and mental processes (<i class="i">think</i>, <i class="i">believe</i>, <i class="i">remember</i>, <i class="i">understand</i> etc.):</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The food was terrible. I <b class="b">could taste</b> nothing but salt.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We knew they were in there. We <b class="b">could hear</b> voices inside.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He came and spoke to me, but I <b class="b">couldn’t remember</b> his name.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-expressions-be-able-to-be-due-to#be-expressions-be-able-to-be-due-to__2"><i class="i">Be able to</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Reporting <i class="i"><i class="i">can</i></i></h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i> when reporting clauses with <i class="i">can</i> as past events:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They told us we <b class="b">could</b> wait in the hallway.</i> (The original words were probably: ‘You can wait in the hallway.’)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She said we <b class="b">could</b> book the tickets online.</i> (The speaker remembers hearing ‘You can book the tickets online.’)</p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_4' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Criticism</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We often use <i class="i">could have</i> + -<i class="i">ed</i> form to express disapproval or criticism:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">could have</b> called to say you would be late.</i> (You didn’t call – I think you should have called.)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">could have</b> tidied your room.</i></p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Regret</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We use <i class="i">could have</i> + -<i class="i">ed</i> form to talk about things that did not happen and sometimes to expresses regret:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">could have been</b> a doctor.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">could have been</b> famous.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We often use the expression <i class="i">how could you/she/he/they?</i> to show disapproval (to show that we don’t like what someone has done):</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Grandfather, <b class="b">how could you</b>? <b class="b">How could you</b> leave me?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">How could you</b> have gone without telling me?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">We had to give away our dog when we moved to England</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Oh</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">how could you</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div></blockquote></div></div></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during-or-for"><i>During</i> or <i>for?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/each-or-every"><i>Each</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/east-or-eastern-north-or-northern"><i>East</i> or <i>eastern</i>; <i>north</i> or <i>northern</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i>Economic</i> or <i>economical</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/efficient-or-effective"><i>Efficient</i> or <i>effective</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/elder-eldest-or-older-oldest"><i>Elder</i>, <i>eldest</i> or <i>older</i>, <i>oldest</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/end-or-finish"><i>End</i> or <i>finish</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/especially-or-specially"><i>Especially</i> or <i>specially</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/every"><i>Every one</i> or <i>everyone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/except-or-except-for"><i>Except</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/expect-hope-or-wait"><i>Expect</i>, <i>hope</i> or <i>wait</i>?</a>
</li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/experience-or-experiment"><i>Experience</i> or <i>experiment</i>?</a>

</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/finally-at-last-lastly-or-in-the-end"><i>Finally</i>, <i>at last</i>, <i>lastly</i> or <i>in the end?</i></a>
</li>
<li>

<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>

</li>
<li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>modals and modality</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/can"><i>Can</i></a>
</li>
<li class="current">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could"><i>Could</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could-may-and-might"><i>Could</i>, <i>may</i> and <i>might</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/dare"><i>Dare</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/had-better"><i>Had better</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/may"><i>May</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/might"><i>Might</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-forms">Modality: forms</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-introduction">Modality: introduction</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-meanings-and-uses">Modality: meanings and uses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-modal-words-and-expressions">Modality: other modal words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-verbs">Modality: other verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-tense">Modality: tense</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/must"><i>Must</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/ought-to"><i>Ought to</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/shall"><i>Shall</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/should"><i>Should</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/will"><i>Will</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/would"><i>Would</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">
